# 2003 Cricket World Cup Final

The **2003 Cricket World Cup Final** was a [One Day
International](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") (ODI)
match played between [Australia](/wiki/Australia_national_cricket_team
"Australia national cricket team") and
[India](/wiki/India_national_cricket_team "India national cricket team") on 23
March 2003 at the [Wanderers Stadium](/wiki/Wanderers_Stadium "Wanderers
Stadium") in [Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg"), South Africa.
It marked the culmination of the [2003 Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World Cup"), the eighth
edition of the tournament. It was the first time that these two teams had met
at this stage of a World Cup. For defending champions Australia it was their
fifth World Cup final, while for India it was the second after their [1983
victory](/wiki/1983_Cricket_World_Cup_Final "1983 Cricket World Cup Final").
Australia won the match by 125 [runs](/wiki/Run_\(cricket\) "Run \(cricket\)")
to claim the title for the third time.

Both teams had progressed through three stages to reach the final. Australia
was unbeaten thus far, while India had lost one game—against Australia in the
first stage. Australia—led by [Ricky Ponting](/wiki/Ricky_Ponting "Ricky
Ponting")—entered the game as firm favourites. After winning the
[toss](/wiki/Toss_\(cricket\) "Toss \(cricket\)"), India captain [Sourav
Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav Ganguly") decided to field first before
a crowd of nearly 32,000. The Australian opening pair, [Adam
Gilchrist](/wiki/Adam_Gilchrist "Adam Gilchrist") and [Matthew
Hayden](/wiki/Matthew_Hayden "Matthew Hayden"), added 105 runs in 14
[overs](/wiki/Over_\(cricket\) "Over \(cricket\)"). After their dismissals,
Ponting (140 [not out](/wiki/Not_out_\(cricket\) "Not out \(cricket\)")) and
[Damien Martyn](/wiki/Damien_Martyn "Damien Martyn") (88 not out) were
involved in a [partnership](/wiki/Partnership_\(cricket\) "Partnership
\(cricket\)") of 234 runs, then an Australian record, and took the total to
359 runs at the end of the innings. [Harbhajan Singh](/wiki/Harbhajan_Singh
"Harbhajan Singh") took both of the Australian [wickets](/wiki/Wickets
"Wickets"), conceding 49 runs.

In response, India lost their key batsman, [Sachin
Tendulkar](/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar "Sachin Tendulkar"), at the start of the
innings. Despite a brief interruption by rain after the 17th over, no time was
lost from the game. Once play resumed, India lost wickets at regular
intervals. [Virender Sehwag](/wiki/Virender_Sehwag "Virender Sehwag") top-
scored for India with 82 runs, before the team were bowled out for 234 runs in
the 40th over. For Australia, [Glenn McGrath](/wiki/Glenn_McGrath "Glenn
McGrath") took three wickets for 52 runs, while [Brett Lee](/wiki/Brett_Lee
"Brett Lee") and [Andrew Symonds](/wiki/Andrew_Symonds "Andrew Symonds")
claimed two wickets each. Ponting was named [man of the
match](/wiki/Man_of_the_match "Man of the match") for his 140, and Tendulkar,
the tournament's leading run-scorer (673 runs), was awarded the man of the
series. The final was Australia's seventeenth successive ODI win, a record,
and they were the first team to win three World Cups. Ganguly's decision to
bowl first in the match was criticised by journalists and former cricketers.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

###
Format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Format")]

See also: [History of the Cricket World
Cup](/wiki/History_of_the_Cricket_World_Cup "History of the Cricket World
Cup")

The [2003 Cricket World Cup](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup "2003 Cricket World
Cup") was the eighth [World Cup](/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup "Cricket World Cup"),
organised by the [International Cricket
Council](/wiki/International_Cricket_Council "International Cricket Council")
(ICC). The competition took place between 9 February and 23 March 2003,
lasting 43 days. Co-hosted by South Africa, Zimbabwe and Kenya, the tournament
was the first World Cup to be played in Africa.[3] There were 14 participating
teams, the largest number in a World Cup until then. As well as the 10 Test-
playing nations, four associate teams took part.
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya_national_cricket_team "Kenya national cricket team"), by
virtue of its ODI status, automatically qualified for the tournament;
[Canada](/wiki/Canada_national_cricket_team "Canada national cricket team"),
[Namibia](/wiki/Namibia_national_cricket_team "Namibia national cricket team")
and [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_cricket_team "Netherlands
national cricket team")—the top three teams of the [2001 ICC
Trophy](/wiki/2001_ICC_Trophy "2001 ICC Trophy")—formed the rest.[4]

The structure of the tournament was similar to that of the [1999 World
Cup](/wiki/1999_Cricket_World_Cup "1999 Cricket World Cup"). The 14 countries
were separated into two groups of seven; each team played the others in its
group once. The most successful three from each group qualified for the Super
Sixes stage,[4] a format which was introduced in the 1999 tournament.[3] Each
qualifier carried forward their points from the first stage and played one
game against each of the three teams from the other group. The top four teams
from the Super Sixes qualified for the semi-finals, and the winners of those
matches contested the final. A total of 54 matches were played in the
tournament.[5]

The matches were played according to the standard rules of a [One Day
International](/wiki/One_Day_International "One Day International") (ODI).
Each side batted for a maximum of 50 overs,[b][7] and fielding restrictions
applied for the bowling side. For the first 15 overs only two fielders were
allowed outside the
[infield](/wiki/Fielding_restrictions_\(cricket\)#Men.27s_Fielding_Restriction_Circles
"Fielding restrictions \(cricket\)"), and for the rest of the innings four
fielders (including a bowler and the [wicket-keeper](/wiki/Wicket-keeper
"Wicket-keeper")) had to be deployed in the infield. No player was allowed to
bowl more than 10 overs in an innings.[8]

###
Squads[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Squads")]

Main article: [2003 Cricket World Cup
squads](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup_squads "2003 Cricket World Cup squads")

The [Australian Cricket Board](/wiki/Australian_Cricket_Board "Australian
Cricket Board") announced their squad for the World Cup on 31 December 2002,
but several changes were made to the team before the tournament was completed.
In January 2003, [Shane Watson](/wiki/Shane_Watson "Shane Watson") was ruled
out following a [stress fracture](/wiki/Stress_fracture "Stress fracture") and
was replaced by [Ian Harvey](/wiki/Ian_Harvey "Ian Harvey").[9] A day before
the tournament started, Australia's key [spinner](/wiki/Spin_bowling "Spin
bowling") [Shane Warne](/wiki/Shane_Warne "Shane Warne") was found guilty of
using a prohibited [diuretic](/wiki/Diuretic "Diuretic") drug during an ODI
series held in Australia before the World Cup. He was sent home after he
tested positive, and banned from playing for one year.[10][11] Later,
Australia's fast bowler [Jason Gillespie](/wiki/Jason_Gillespie "Jason
Gillespie") was ruled out from the tournament following a tendon injury.[12]
Warne and Gillespie were replaced by [Nathan Hauritz](/wiki/Nathan_Hauritz
"Nathan Hauritz") (on 24 February 2003) and [Nathan
Bracken](/wiki/Nathan_Bracken "Nathan Bracken") (on 5 March 2003),
respectively.[13][14] An ongoing dispute between the [Board for Control of
Cricket in India](/wiki/Board_for_Control_of_Cricket_in_India "Board for
Control of Cricket in India") (BCCI) and the Indian players over product
endorsements ensured a delay in the announcement of a provisional squad for
the World Cup.[15] The BCCI announced the final selection of 15 members on 31
December 2002.[16] [Sachin Tendulkar](/wiki/Sachin_Tendulkar "Sachin
Tendulkar") made into the final squad despite three ongoing injuries,
including a major one on the ankle.[17]

Having won 15 out of their 18 ODIs leading up the start of the tournament, the
defending champions Australia were deemed one of the favourites to reach the
semi-finals.[18] They had previously won the
[1987](/wiki/1987_Cricket_World_Cup "1987 Cricket World Cup") and 1999
tournaments. In contrast, some commentators considered it doubtful whether
India would qualify for the Super Sixes stage. They had won the competition
once, [in 1983](/wiki/1983_Cricket_World_Cup "1983 Cricket World Cup"), but
had recently lost an ODI series against [West
Indies](/wiki/West_Indies_cricket_team "West Indies cricket team") at home,
and were defeated heavily in their tour of [New
Zealand](/wiki/Indian_cricket_team_in_New_Zealand_in_2002%E2%80%9303 "Indian
cricket team in New Zealand in 2002–03").[19][20]

## Route to the
final[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Route to the final")]

### Group
stage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Group stage")]

Main article: [2003 Cricket World Cup group
stage](/wiki/2003_Cricket_World_Cup_group_stage "2003 Cricket World Cup group
stage")

Australia and India were both in Pool A of the competition. Australia won all
their matches in the group stage. Except for their win against England, when
they recovered from 135 for 8 to reach the target of 205
[runs](/wiki/Run_\(cricket\) "Run \(cricket\)"), they won all their matches
comfortably.[12]

India had a shaky start to the tournament.[12] In their opening match against
the [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_cricket_team "Netherlands cricket team"),
they were bowled out for 204 runs. Although they won the game by 79 runs, the
team was criticised for failing to bat out their 50 overs.[21] After they were
dismissed for 125 runs against Australia and lost the match by nine wickets,
angry fans in India burned effigies of the players; [Mohammad
Kaif](/wiki/Mohammad_Kaif "Mohammad Kaif")'s house and [Rahul
Dravid](/wiki/Rahul_Dravid "Rahul Dravid")'s car were vandalised.[22][23]
India won all the remaining games of the stage—against Zimbabwe, Pakistan,
Namibia and England.[17]

Australia, India and Zimbabwe finished the group as the top three teams and
qualified for the Super Sixes from Pool A,[19] while Pool B had Sri Lanka,
Kenya and New Zealand progress for the next stage.[12]

### Super
Sixes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Super Sixes")]

In the first match of the Super Sixes against Sri Lanka, Australia made 319
runs for five wickets. The Australian captain [Ricky
Ponting](/wiki/Ricky_Ponting "Ricky Ponting") and his deputy, [Adam
Gilchrist](/wiki/Adam_Gilchrist "Adam Gilchrist"),[24] scored 114 not out and
99 respectively. Sri Lanka in reply managed 223 runs in 47.4 overs. [Aravinda
de Silva](/wiki/Aravinda_de_Silva "Aravinda de Silva") top-scored with 92
while [Brett Lee](/wiki/Brett_Lee "Brett Lee") captured three wickets for
Australia.[25] In the next match against New Zealand, [Shane
Bond](/wiki/Shane_Bond "Shane Bond")'s six wickets for 23 runs reduced
Australia to 84 runs for seven wickets in 27 overs before [Michael
Bevan](/wiki/Michael_Bevan "Michael Bevan") and [Andrew
Bichel](/wiki/Andrew_Bichel "Andrew Bichel") took the total to 208 runs.[26]
Lee's five wickets for 42 runs helped to bowl New Zealand out for 112 runs,
their lowest total in World Cup.[27] Australia won their final game by five
wickets after bowling out Kenya for 174 runs.[28]

After losing the toss against Kenya in their first match, India were set a
target of 226 runs. Despite an initial collapse, their captain [Sourav
Ganguly](/wiki/Sourav_Ganguly "Sourav Ganguly") (107 not out) and [Yuvraj
Singh](/wiki/Yuvraj_Singh "Yuvraj Singh") (58 not out) ensured India's
victory.[29] In the next game against Sri Lanka, India made 292 runs;
Tendulkar (97) and Sehwag (66) top-scored for the team. Srinath took four
wickets as Sri Lanka were bowled out for 109, and India won the match by a
margin of 183 runs.[30] In their final match of the stage, India played New
Zealand. [Zaheer Khan](/wiki/Zaheer_Khan "Zaheer Khan") returned career-best
[figures](/wiki/Bowling_analysis "Bowling analysis") of four wickets for 42
runs, and New Zealand were dismissed for 146 runs. India lost three wickets
for 21 runs, before Dravid, their vice-captain,[16] and Kaif added 129 runs
for the fourth wicket and ensured a seven-wicket win. The match marked the
seventh consecutive victory for India in the tournament.[31]

### Semi-
finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Semi-finals")]

The first semi-final was played between Australia and Sri Lanka on 18 March at
[St. George's Park](/wiki/St_George%27s_Park,_Port_Elizabeth "St George's
Park, Port Elizabeth"), [Port Elizabeth](/wiki/Port_Elizabeth "Port
Elizabeth"). Australia won the toss and opted to bat first. They managed 212
runs for the loss of 7 wickets at the end of 50 overs. Symonds top-scored for
the team with 91 [not out](/wiki/Not_out_\(cricket\) "Not out \(cricket\)"),
while [Chaminda Vaas](/wiki/Chaminda_Vaas "Chaminda Vaas") picked up three
wickets for Sri Lanka.[32] With 213 runs needed for victory, Sri Lanka lost
both the openers after which the play was interrupted by rain. The target was
revised to 172 runs from 38.1 overs using the [Duckworth–Lewis
method](/wiki/Duckworth%E2%80%93Lewis_method "Duckworth–Lewis method"), a
mathematical formulation used to calculate revised targets for teams batting
second in case of matches being interrupted by bad weather or rain.[33] [Kumar
Sangakkara](/wiki/Kumar_Sangakkara "Kumar Sangakkara") and Vaas made 47 runs
together for the eighth wicket, the highest partnership of the innings, but
the team managed to score only 123 runs in the allotted overs. Australia
progressed into the final as Sri Lanka fell 48 runs short of the target.[34]

The second semi-final was played between India and Kenya on 20 March 2003 at
[Kingsmead](/wiki/Kingsmead_Cricket_Ground "Kingsmead Cricket Ground"),
[Durban](/wiki/Durban "Durban"). Kenya became the first non-Test team to play
a World Cup semi-final.[35][36] India won the toss and made 270 runs for four
wickets. Ganguly and Tendulkar made 111 not out and 83 respectively.[37] In
reply, Kenya were bowled out for 179 in 46.2 overs. Their captain Steve Tikolo
top-scored with 56 runs, while Zaheer Khan took three wickets for 14 runs.
Ganguly was adjudged the [Man of the match](/wiki/Man_of_the_match "Man of the
match").[38]

## Build
up[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Build up")]

Many journalists considered Australia, undefeated throughout the tournament,
to be favourites in the final.[39][40] The Indian industrialist [Vijay
Mallya](/wiki/Vijay_Mallya "Vijay Mallya") organised special flights,
including a few [chartered ones](/wiki/Air_charter "Air charter"), to
transport film actors, politicians and businessmen to
[Johannesburg](/wiki/Johannesburg "Johannesburg");[41] most of these people
supported India. Some South African airlines also extended their support to
India.[42] The air tickets from Mumbai to Johannesburg were completely sold
out immediately after India entered the Super Sixes stage.[43] Although most
journalists and analysts favoured Australia, former [Pakistan
captain](/wiki/List_of_Pakistan_national_cricket_captains "List of Pakistan
national cricket captains") [Imran Khan](/wiki/Imran_Khan "Imran Khan")
believed India were favourites. Former Australia cricketer [Greg
Chappell](/wiki/Greg_Chappell "Greg Chappell") complimented Brett Lee: he
said, except for Lee, no Australian bowler was a serious threat to the Indian
batsmen, and also remarked that the "duel" between Lee and Tendulkar would be
crucial.[44]

On the eve of the match, which would be his 100th ODI as India's captain,
Ganguly issued a statement saying that his team were honoured to play the
World Cup final. He cited India's victories at the 1983 World Cup and the 1985
World Championship of Cricket as his inspirations.[45] Although acknowledging
Australia as the best side in the world, he stated that they were not
"unbeatable".[46] Australia's main concern was Tendulkar, the tournament's
top-scorer, of whom the Indian fans had high expectations.[12] Ponting hinted
about the possibility that his bowlers, Lee and [Glenn
McGrath](/wiki/Glenn_McGrath "Glenn McGrath"), had "special" plans to restrict
him.[46] He also said that in crucial matches his team "tries to reach another
level".[47]

Before the match, the two teams had faced each other eight times in World
Cups; Australia had won six of them.[48] In the 2003 tournament, Australia won
all their matches to that point; India's only defeat came in the group stage
against Australia.[c][47] For all the Indian players it was their first World
Cup final, whereas six of the Australians had appeared in at least one
previous final.[49]

##
Final[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Final")]

###
Summary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Summary")]

The final was played on 23 March 2003 at the [Wanderers
Stadium](/wiki/Wanderers_Stadium "Wanderers Stadium"), Johannesburg. This was
the fifth match to be played at the ground in the tournament.[50] The match,
watched by a crowd of 31,779,[a] began at 10:00
[SAST](/wiki/South_African_Standard_Time "South African Standard Time").[51]
[Simon Wilde](/wiki/Simon_Wilde "Simon Wilde"), writing for the _[Wisden
Cricketers' Almanack](/wiki/Wisden_Cricketers%27_Almanack "Wisden Cricketers'
Almanack")_, said the venue was one of the "most bountiful" grounds for
batsmen.[12] However, on that day the [pitch](/wiki/Pitch_\(cricket\) "Pitch
\(cricket\)") was moist and the outfield was damp as a result of the
thunderstorms the previous evening. A short shower that morning forced the
ground staff to blow dry air over the pitch. The sky was overcast with a
chance of further rainfall.[52] For the umpires—[David
Shepherd](/wiki/David_Shepherd_\(umpire\) "David Shepherd \(umpire\)") and
[Steve Bucknor](/wiki/Steve_Bucknor "Steve Bucknor")—it was their third World
Cup Final.[53] [Rudi Koertzen](/wiki/Rudi_Koertzen "Rudi Koertzen") and [Billy
Bowden](/wiki/Billy_Bowden "Billy Bowden") were appointed as the
[third](/wiki/Third_umpire "Third umpire") and [fourth](/wiki/Fourth_umpire
"Fourth umpire") umpires, respectively. Former Sri Lankan cricketer [Ranjan
Madugalle](/wiki/Ranjan_Madugalle "Ranjan Madugalle") served as the [match
referee](/wiki/Match_referee "Match referee").[1]

[![The Wanderers stadium \(pictured\) under
floodlights](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/The_Wanderers_2.jpg/220px-
The_Wanderers_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_Wanderers_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_Wanderers_2.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Wanderers Stadium](/wiki/Wanderers_Stadium "Wanderers Stadium")
_(pictured in 2007)_

India remained unchanged from the side that played the semi-final, while
Australia excluded Ian Harvey and brought back [Damien
Martyn](/wiki/Damien_Martyn "Damien Martyn") into the side. Ganguly won the
toss and elected to field first.[52] Zaheer Khan opened the bowling for India
along with [Javagal Srinath](/wiki/Javagal_Srinath "Javagal Srinath"). The
Australian openers scored aggressively from the beginning of the innings as
Khan conceded 15 runs in the first over.[54] Gilchrist in particular hit both
Khan and Srinath for many runs and reached his 50 from 40 balls. When Ganguly
turned to his spin bowlers as early as the tenth over, Gilchrist slowed his
scoring rate. In the fourteenth over, when [Harbhajan
Singh](/wiki/Harbhajan_Singh "Harbhajan Singh") was brought back to bowl,
Gilchrist (57 off 48 balls) tried to hit him over the [mid-
wicket](/wiki/Fielding_\(cricket\)#midwicket "Fielding \(cricket\)"), but was
beaten by the ball's extra bounce and caught in the deep by [Virender
Sehwag](/wiki/Virender_Sehwag "Virender Sehwag").[54] The pair had added 105
runs for the first wicket.[55] Harbhajan struck again in the twentieth over
when he dismissed Hayden (37 runs off 54 balls), leaving the score at 125
runs.[54]

After Hayden's departure, Ponting was joined by Martyn, who completed his
half-century in 46 balls.[55] Ponting scored at a slower rate, reaching his 50
off 74 balls with one four. After completing his half century, he accelerated;
he hit two [sixes](/wiki/Six_\(cricket\) "Six \(cricket\)") off Harbhajan and
one off [Ashish Nehra](/wiki/Ashish_Nehra "Ashish Nehra").[55] The pair added
100 runs off 109 balls for the third wicket. Ponting reached his century
quickly—his second fifty came off 29 balls.[55] At the end of the innings,
Australia had scored 359 runs for two wickets;[d] Ponting had scored 140 not
out (off 121 balls; four [fours](/wiki/Four_\(cricket\) "Four \(cricket\)")
and eight sixes)[e] and Martyn hit 88 not out (off 84 balls; seven fours and
one six) respectively. As of the [2015
competition](/wiki/2015_Cricket_World_Cup "2015 Cricket World Cup"), Ponting's
innings remains the highest individual score by a captain in a World Cup
final,[56] and Australia's total remains the highest by a team in a World Cup
final. The 234-run stand between Ponting and Marytn was a record partnership
for Australia in ODIs at that point in time.[f] The Indian bowlers conceded 37
[extras](/wiki/Extra_\(cricket\) "Extra \(cricket\)"). Srinath conceded 87
runs without taking a wicket—the most expensive figures in his career—in what
was his last international game.[54]

India came out to bat with Tendulkar and Sehwag. McGrath opened the bowling
for Australia. Tendulkar hit a boundary off the fourth ball of the over but
was dismissed off the next delivery.[54] Ganguly joined Sehwag and the pair
scored at a run-a-ball before the former was dismissed by Lee in the tenth
over. Kaif, the next man, was dismissed in the same over with the score 59
runs for 3 wickets. Dravid and Sehwag scored steadily from then on until the
seventeenth over,[21] when rain interrupted play with the score at 103
runs.[54] After play resumed, Ponting brought in Australia's spinners, [Brad
Hogg](/wiki/Brad_Hogg "Brad Hogg") and [Darren Lehmann](/wiki/Darren_Lehmann
"Darren Lehmann"). Sehwag was more aggressive against both, hitting Lehmann
for three consecutive fours and Hogg for a four and six; Dravid played a
secondary role to Sehwag, pushing often for singles. They were dismissed in
quick succession after making 82 (off 81 balls) and 47 (off 57 balls)
respectively.[54] Following that, India began to lose wickets at regular
intervals. Except for Yuvraj Singh (24) and Dinesh Mongia (12), the rest of
the players were out for single-digit scores.[54] India were bowled out for
234 runs in 39.2 overs when Zaheer Khan was dismissed by McGrath.[58]
Australia won the match by 125 runs, the largest margin of victory by runs in
a World Cup final.[59] It was their second successive World Cup trophy and
their third overall.[60] Ponting was declared the Man of the match for his 140
not out.[2]

##
Aftermath[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2003_Cricket_World_Cup_Final&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Aftermath")]

Australia became the first team to win three World Cups,[54] and registered a
record 17 consecutive ODI wins.[61] They also became the first team to win all
the matches in a World Cup tournament.[62] Writing for the _Wisden Cricketers
' Almanack_, Simon Wilde remarked that Australia would have beaten a Rest of
the World XI had they been asked.[12]

At the post-match press conference, Ponting said the Indian players showed no
signs of winning the match at any point in time. On Australia's win he said,
"It's not that we think we are ahead of the others. It's just the way we
play."[47] Nevertheless, he complimented both teams by saying that India and
Australia were the two best teams in the tournament, and said that the Indian
players deserved to be in the final.[47] Ganguly praised the Australian
batsmen and said that they played like "real champions".[63]

Ganguly's decision to bowl first was criticised by the media: _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , for instance, said it
"backfired horribly".[60][64] Former Pakistan captain Imran Khan, while
denouncing Ganguly's decision, also criticised his idea of going into the
match with an unchanged side. He stated that India should have played their
[leg spinner](/wiki/Leg_spin "Leg spin") [Anil Kumble](/wiki/Anil_Kumble "Anil
Kumble") as the ball was "gripping [in] the surface".[65] The journalist and
former England cricketer [Mike Selvey](/wiki/Mike_Selvey "Mike Selvey")
believed that Ganguly may have been influenced by the possibility of the
Duckworth–Lewis method affecting the result.[66] Indian journalist [Boria
Majumdar](/wiki/Boria_Majumdar "Boria Majumdar") in his book, _Cricketing
Cultures in Conflict_ (2004), remarked about the possibility of Australia
losing the rain-interrupted final, if the result were to be decided by this
method.[67] Ganguly defended his decision saying that the overcast conditions
and moisture in the pitch meant it was favourable to the bowlers, but they
failed to use it properly.[52] Ponting said that he would have opted to bat
first had they won the toss.[68] His teammate Symonds, in an interview later,
recalled that India's decision to bowl first gave them an impression that they
were not "confident enough to take the fight".[69]

Australia were rewarded with prize money totaling US$2,000,000, while India
received $800,000.[35][70] Tendulkar's aggregate of 673 runs in the tournament
fetched him the Man of the series accolade.[g][12] Ponting's innings of 140
not out was placed among the best innings of the tournament by
[Rediff](/wiki/Rediff "Rediff"),[72] and among the top 10 performances in a
World Cup final by the ICC.[73] Tendulkar and Hayden were included among the
"Highest impact World XI", a World Cup team released by the _Wisden_ India
owned website Impact Index, in February 2015.[74] Srinath, who was then
India's leading wicket-taker in ODIs, retired a few months after the
competition.[75] The match also marked the end of India coach [John
Wright](/wiki/John_Wright_\(cricketer\) "John Wright \(cricketer\)")'s
contract.[76] On his request the [Board of Control for Cricket in
India](/wiki/Board_of_Control_for_Cricket_in_India "Board of Control for
Cricket in India") retained his position in which he continued to serve until
2005.[77][78]
